Mn–Co–Al–Mg mixed oxides by auto-combustion method and their use as catalysts in the total oxidation of toluene María Haidy Castaño Rafael Molina Sonia Moreno ⁎ Estado Sólido y Catálisis Ambiental (ESCA), Departamento de Química, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Kra 30 N° 45-03, Bogotá, Colombia ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +57 1 3165000; fax: +57 1 3165220. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Manganese and cobalt catalysts were prepared from two different procedures. ► The auto-combustion improved the redox properties in manganese oxides. ► Mn reacts faster than Co with the glycine, producing oxides with better properties in oxidation. ► Manganese oxides are more sensitive to the synthesis method than the cobalt oxides. ► Successful oxidation of toluene was obtained over manganese oxides by auto-combustion. Manganese oxides were prepared by the auto-combustion method and while employing variable Mn/Mg ratios from 0.1 to 1.0 with glycine as a combustible and a glycine/nitrate=1 ratio. The Mn/Mg ratio that showed the best activity in the oxidation of toluene was maintained in order to synthesize the hydrotalcite structure by the co-precipitation method, which by calcination, allows the formation of a mixed oxide. Cobalt oxides were prepared by the two synthesis methods while maintaining the best metal charge (corresponding to the best catalytic behavior). The obtained solids were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray fluorescence (XRF), temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and surface area measurements, and the catalytic activity for the complete toluene oxidation was evaluated. The results revealed that the auto-combustion catalysts are obtained in very short times and that their physico-chemical and catalytic properties are the same or higher than those of the co-precipitation catalysts. The solid with the Mn/Mg=1 ratio is the most active and selective catalyst and shows more activity than the oxide obtained by the co-precipitation method. The redox behavior in the manganese catalysts depends on the preparation method, which, in the case of auto-combustion, avoids the segregation of phases. The manganese reacts faster than the cobalt with the glycine and produces oxides with better properties in oxidation reactions. On the contrary, the cobalt oxides prepared by the two synthesis methods with a Co/Mg=1 ratio presented similar results in toluene oxidation. Keywords Organic compounds Mixed oxides Toluene oxidation Mn–Co oxides Catalytic properties 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are principle air pollutants because they react with the nitrogen oxides present in the atmosphere and produce an accumulation of tropospheric ozone and photo-chemical compounds, which deteriorate air quality and human health [1]. A wide variety of organic compounds are included in the term VOCs, such as hydrocarbons, aldehydes, ketones, alcohols, glycols, and ethers, all of which are emitted into the atmosphere due to their use in industrial processes related to textiles, solvents, cleaners and printing industries [2]. Catalytic oxidation is one of the most important and promising options for the elimination of VOCs because the catalysts can work at low temperatures, reduce the NOx generated by other treatment methods and, in general, present a high destructive efficiency [3]. Catalysts based on noble metals (Pd, Pt, Au) show high activities for eliminating hydrocarbons, but their resistance to poisoning in severe reaction conditions is lower. Manganese and cobalt oxides are known for their high catalytic activity in the oxidation of organic compounds due to their redox properties, their high resistance to sintering and for being cheaper than the noble metals [1,4,5]. The catalytic properties of manganese oxides are attributed to the ability of the metal to form oxides within a wide range of stoichiometries and crystal phases (β-MnO2, γ-MnO2, α-Mn2O3, γ-Mn2O3, α-Mn3O4, and Mn5O8), where Mn atoms are found in various oxidation states. Manganese oxides are also known for their oxygen storage capacity within the crystalline network and the formation of amorphous solid structures, which have vacancies that promote oxidation reactions [6–12]. On the other hand, cobalt oxide is among the most promising metal oxides for the removal of CO and VOCs because of the presence of mobile oxygen within the Co3O4 structure [13,14]. The high activity of this oxide in CO oxidation is attributed to the weak strength of the CoO bond, which creates an easy interaction of the network oxygen with the reactants [15–17]. Co3O4 has been reported as one of the best catalysts for propene and toluene oxidation [18,19]. It is known that mixed metal oxides are more active than the single ones [20]. These mixed oxide catalysts can be easily obtained through the thermal decomposition of LDH precursors, which are usually prepared by the co-precipitation of aqueous solutions of MII and MIII salts in alkaline media. Heating LDHs at moderate temperatures results in finely dispersed mixed oxides of MII and MIII with large surface areas and good thermal stabilities. Various LDH-related mixed oxides have been reported as good catalysts for the total oxidation of VOCs [18,21–23]. The synthesis method plays a fundamental role in the design of catalysts because the textural, structural and catalytic properties of the solids can be modulated. The auto-combustion method is an interesting, alternate, accessible and faster method for the preparation of mixed oxides with identical or better properties than LDH-related mixed oxides. Auto-combustion is an oxidation–reduction reaction between a combustible and an oxidant (F/O) that leads to the generation of gaseous products (CO2, H2O and N2) and to oxides with very interesting properties and with diverse areas of application [24–26]. During auto-combustion, the evolution of gaseous products leads to a dissipation of heat and limits increases in temperature and reduces sintering. Additionally, this method leads to porous structures that facilitate adsorption and diffusion of reactant molecules and generates materials with narrow particle size ranges, good metallic dispersion and inter-particle distances between active phases with a partial elimination of the external energy and without requiring subsequent chemical processes [27–29]. Mixed oxides can be attained by the auto-combustion method in very short periods of synthesis with the same or better physical–chemical and catalytic properties as the ones obtained by co-precipitation. Furthermore, we find that the autocombustion method improves the dispersion of the active phase and the redox properties which directly influence the catalytic performance of the materials. In this paper, Mn–Mg–Al and Co–Mg–Al oxides were prepared by two different methods, auto-combustion and co-precipitation. The effects of the Mn and Co load on the textural, structural and redox properties were studied. Toluene was chosen for evaluating the catalytic performance of solids because it is a representative VOC of aromatic compounds. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Mn and Co oxides were synthesized by employing the auto-combustion technique (AC). For the manganese oxides, nitrates of Mg2+, Al3+, and Mn2+ were mixed while maintaining a M2+/M3+ =3 ratio (suitable for obtaining HT structure) and Mn2+/Mg2+ variable ratios of 0.1, 0.36, 0.5 and 1.0. Glycine was used as fuel (F) in order to maintain a glycine/nitrate 1/1 ratio [30]. The nitrate solution was added to the glycine with constant stirring. The resulting solution was slowly evaporated until a gel was obtained. The gel was heated to approximately 250°C, which is the temperature at which the ignition reaction occurs. Once the ignition reaction occurred, a powder was obtained, and it was calcined at 500°C for 4h to eliminate the remaining residuals and to obtain the corresponding mixed oxide. For the preparation of cobalt oxide, the Mn2+/Mg2+ ratio that provided the best catalytic behavior was chosen, and the procedure was the same only replacing the Mn with Co. On the other hand, Mn and Co oxides were obtained using the simultaneous co-precipitation technique while maintaining a M2+/M3+ =3 ratio and preserving the Mn2+/Mg2+ ratio chosen in the synthesis for auto-combustion [31]. Mg2+, Al3+, Mn2+ or Co2+ nitrates were mixed and added drop-wise to a 0.2M of K2CO3 solution with constant stirring; the pH was maintained between 9.5 and 10.5 by an addition of 1M NaOH solution. The resulting precipitate was aged for 18h without stirring. Subsequently, the solid was washed and dried at 60°C in air for 24h to obtain the HT precursor and then calcined at 500°C for 16h to obtain the respective mixed oxide. 2.2 Characterization X-ray diffraction analysis was carried out with a SHIMADZU LAB-X XRD-6000 diffractometer equipped with a Cu anode.Chemical analysis was carried out with a MagixPro PW-2440 Phillips X-ray fluorescence spectrometer equipped with a Rh tube and with a maximum potency of 4kW. The H2-TPR profiles were taken with a CHEMBET 3000 QUANTACHROME equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. The samples (100mg) were previously degasified at 400°C for 1h in an Ar flux and reduced using a mix at 10% (v/v) H2/Ar (30mL/min) and a heating velocity of 10°C/min. Electron microscopy studies (TEM) were carried out with HITACHI H800 instrument operating at 200kV. The BET specific surface areas were measured by nitrogen adsorption at 77K using a Micrometrics ASAP 2020 analyzer. 2.2.1 Catalytic evaluation The solids were evaluated in the catalytic oxidation of toluene. A fixed bed reactor at atmospheric pressure was used with a WHSV of 84,000mL/(gh), 0.200g of the catalyst (<250μm) and a concentration of toluene of 600ppm. The catalysts were pretreated with air flow at 400°C for 2h. The ignition curve was obtained by cooling at 1.5°C/min from 450°C to 100°C. The temperature was measured by a thermocouple placed in the middle of the catalyst bed. The reactants and products of the reaction were analyzed in line with a Shimadzu GC-17A gas chromatograph, and the CO2 production was analyzed by a Bacharach Model 3150 CO2 analyzer equipped with an IR detector. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Manganese oxides The nomenclature relating to the synthesized solids is indicated in Table 1 , where AC refers to obtaining the solid by auto-combustion and CP refers to the solid obtained by co-precipitation. The XRD patterns of manganese oxides prepared by auto-combustion with variable Mn/Mg ratios are presented in Fig. 1 . The diffractograms exhibit signals characteristic of the MgO periclase phase (JCPDS N° 45-0946) and the hausmanite phase Mn3O4 (JCPDS N° 24-0734) together with Mn2MgO4 and Mn2AlO4 spinel-type phases (JCPDS N° 23-0392 and JCPDS N° 29-0881). The signals at 18.5°, 35.7°, and 58.1° 2θ can also be attributed to the Mn5O8 phase (JCPDS N° 39-1218) but these signals are overlapped on the other manganese oxide species. The high reaction temperatures reached in the AC method can favor the formation of these spinel-type phases.The solid with the lowest Mn content (ACMn0.1) forms a periclase phase and a lesser degree, manganese oxide phases. An increase in the manganese load widens the signals of the Mn oxides and reduces the signals characteristic of the periclase phase at 43° and 63° 2θ.Solids ACMn0.36, ACMn0.5 and ACMn1.0 present signals at 18.5°, 35.7°, 43.3°, 58.1° and 63.3° 2θ, which are characteristic of manganese spinel-type oxides whose maxima are difficult to differentiate. Additionally, the signals at 18.5°, 35.7°, and 58.1° 2θ can be attributed to the Mn5O8 phase.Even though the increase in the manganese load can reduce the dispersion because of the growth of the particle size, the XRD pattern of ACMn1.0 shows the same signals and intensity as ACMn0.36 and ACMn0.5.ACMn1.0 presents good dispersion of the active phase attributed to the short duration of the combustion process and to the formation of gaseous products that inhibit the growth of particles and avoid the formation of aggregates on the surface [32]. The diffractogram of the manganese oxide sample obtained by the co-precipitation method (CPMn1.0) with a Mn/Mg=1.0 ratio appears in Fig. 2 . The solid produces signals at 17.8°, 28.8°, 32.4°, 35.9°, 44.2°, 58.3°, 60.0° and 64.4° 2θ; these signals are characteristic of the hausmanite phase or other spinel-type phases. The signals associated to the periclase phase appear at a lower intensity. Fig. 2 shows a larger crystalline structure in the catalyst prepared by the co-precipitation method related to the aging process, which favors crystal growth and phase segregation. On the contrary, in the AC method, the dispersion of the particles is maximized by the fast combustion reaction and the rapid evolution of a large volume of the gaseous products during the combustion which dissipates the heat of combustion and limits the rise of temperature, reducing the possibility of sintering of the particles and also helps in limiting the inter-particle contact. Additionally, the rapid combustion process contributes to the rapid formation of the solids and the possible creation of defects during crystallization. A better dispersion of the oxides obtained by the autocombustion method explains why the signals in the XRD patterns of the manganese series obtained by AC are less defined than those of the co-precipitation oxide [30,33,34]. The Scherrer equation was used to estimate the crystallite size for ACMn1.0 and CPMn1.0 employing the diffraction angle of the plane (211) of the Mn3O4. The particle sizes calculated were of 9±3nm and 34±3nm, respectively. This result verifies the incidence of the preparation method on the dispersion of the particles. The chemical analysis of the solids obtained by XRF is presented in Table 1. In the majority of manganese catalysts obtained by AC, a M2+/M3+ ratio very close to 3 is observed. Manganese oxides obtained from this methodology are very similar to the oxides attained by co-precipitation, which stem from hydrotalcite type materials. Likewise, an identical M2+/M3+ ratio for the equivalent solids ACMn1.0 and CMMn1.0 is demonstrated as well as Mn2+/Mg2+ ratio of 1.34 and 1.24, respectively; this outcome indicates an effective incorporation of manganese by both synthesis methods. Fig. 3 shows the result of the H2-TPR profiles for the mixed oxides prepared by auto-combustion and by the co-precipitation method. In general, the samples present a complex profile associated to the multiple oxidation states and different chemical environments of manganese. Nevertheless, three main zones are observed; a low temperature zone (<300°C), an intermediate zone (300–550°C) and a third high temperature zone (>600°C). In the first zone, wide and poorly defined signals are observed and assigned to MnOx species (mixture of oxides Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+) with different particle sizes and reactivities which probably correspond to the Mn5O8 phase and its possible transformation to Mn2O3 [22,35]. The second zone (300–550°C) is attributed to the transition of Mn2O3 to Mn3O4 and to the reduction of Mn3O4 species toward MnO [10,22,36,37]. As is shown in the sequence of the solids prepared by AC, an increase in the Mn load facilitates the formation of the Mn3O4 species. In effect, the solid with the highest load (ACMn1.0) presents the most intense signal at the transition Mn3O4 →MnO; this outcome favors the catalytic behavior in oxidation reactions. It has been established that manganese oxides with Mn atoms in different states of oxidation such as Mn3O4 (MnIIMn2 IIIO4), contain an optimum electronic mobility that promotes oxidation–reduction reactions on the surface [8]. In the third zone, the peaks in the range of 600–900°C are attributed to the presence of the spinel phases and the manganese, which forms part of the solid solution as shown by XRD. For the solid with the least Mn load (ACMn0.1), the signals in this zone are displaced at greater temperatures than in the case of the oxides with a greater manganese charge; this phenomenon is evidence of strong interactions between the metal and the solid solution. Therefore a lesser capacity for the reduction of the manganese species is present in the material ACMn0.1 [21]. On the other hand, the manganese oxide prepared by the co-precipitation presents the same reduction zones as the solids obtained by auto-combustion. More defined signals are observed at 380, 490, 520 and 760°C that correspond to the gradual reduction of Mn2O3 →Mn3O4 →MnO and to the spinel phases that can be present in the solid [22]. Table 2 presents the total hydrogen consumption in the reductive process of the manganese oxides. Likewise, hydrogen consumption at temperatures lower than 500°C is presented because that temperature range is where the redox behavior of the solids under catalytic reaction conditions occurs. An increase in total hydrogen consumption is observed as the Mn load increases. Although the equivalent solids ACMn1.0 and CPMn1.0, prepared by the two different synthesis methodologies, present a similar value in the total consumption of hydrogen, the oxide prepared by auto-combustion shows the greatest hydrogen consumption at temperatures lower than 500°C. This result can be attributed to the presence of better dispersed MnOx species or to a greater content of the Mn3O4 phase as shown in the H2-TPR profiles. Figs. 4 and 5 show TEM micrographs of ACMn1.0 and CPMn1.0. The TEM images of the solid ACMn1.0 (Fig. 4A and B) present aggregates of particles with a heterogeneous morphology and particle size. The darker points probably correspond to manganese nano-oxides (an element which has the greatest atomic weight). A heterogeneous distribution in particle size over the surface is observed. The particle size is mainly in the 20–25nm range. The TEM micrograph for solid OMMn1.0 shows dark zones which probably correspond to oxidic species having a spherical morphology with diverse sizes (Fig. 5). The particle sizes are principally between 100 and 120nm. The results evidence a better dispersion of the oxidic species in ACMn1.0. The dispersion is attributed to the evolution of gaseous species during the process of autocombustion which avoid the growth of particles and improve the distance between them [38,39]. The adsorption–desorption isotherms of the manganese oxides prepared by AC and CP are shown in Fig. 6 . All of the manganese oxides prepared by auto-combustion reveal type IV isotherms in accordance with the IUPAC classification corresponding to principally mesoporous materials with H3 type hysteresis characteristic of pore agglomerates in slit form with non-uniform sizes and shapes [40,41]. In all cases, the area is mainly external (without micropores), which can be attributed to the short synthesis times during auto-combustion. Upon generating gases, such as CO2 and H2O, the short synthesis times produce a template effect and lead to materials with great porosity [30]. The manganese load has no important effect on the specific area of the synthesized solids and all the oxides present similar areas (Table 1). CPMn1.0 presents a type II isotherm characteristic of macroporous materials [41]. The area of this solid is attributable to the formation of pores resulting from the destruction of the laminar spaces of the hydrotalcite after calcinations (loss of water and carbonates). CPMn1.0 presents a type II isotherm characteristic of macroporous materials [41]. The area of this solid is attributable to the formation of pores resulting from the destruction of the laminar spaces of the hydrotalcite after calcinations (loss of water and carbonates). The specific areas of solids ACMn1.0 and CPMn1.0 are the same; the synthesis methods employed in this work determine the form and pore size of the resulting materials. The presence of a broad pore size distribution is confirmed by the occurrence of a rather broad BJH pore diameter distribution in the mesopore size region together with the formation of some macropores by the coprecipitation method (Fig. 7 ). Thus, ACMn1.0 prepared by auto-combustion presents a more narrow pore distribution than the solid CPMn1.0 obtained by co-precipitation. This observation suggests that auto-combustion with a F/O=1 ratio leads to obtaining solids whose pores are more uniform than those in the solid obtained by the co-precipitation method. The catalytic behavior of the materials was evaluated in the toluene oxidation, and the results are presented in Fig. 8 and Table 3 . The temperatures at which 50 and 90% of toluene conversion is attained (T 50 and T 90) are used to compare the catalytic activity of the materials. The ACMn1.0 solid presents the highest conversion and has lower T 50 and T 90 values than the catalysts with lower manganese loads (0.1, 0.36 and 0.5) without surpassing the catalyst of reference (Pt/Al2O3) [5]. However, the catalytic results we found are the same or higher than the catalytic behavior of some oxides that are reported in the literature (Table 3) [6,42,43]. The effect of the Mn content on the catalytic activity can be related to the phases present in the solids obtained by AC, as shown by the results obtained by H2-TPR in which the highest proportion of the Mn3O4 phase is evidenced in the solid with the greater Mn load. Although a direct relation is observed between the manganese load and the increase in the activity of the solid, we found that the ratio Mn/Mg=2 shows the same catalytic, textural, structural and reductive results as ACMn1.0, where the Mn/Mg=1. Therefore, ACMn1.0 was chosen as representative catalyst to exhibit the better properties in the Mn–Mg–Al series prepared by AC. For the samples with the same Mn/Mg=1 ratio but prepared by auto-combustion or co-precipitation (ACMn1.0 and CPMn1.0), the preparation method has an effect on the catalytic activity. The catalyst prepared by the auto-combustion method has the best catalytic performance for toluene oxidation. These results are associated with the properties provided by the auto-combustion synthesis, such as a good dispersion of the active phase, adequate inter-particle distance, formation of defects and a favorable porosity that allows access to the active sites [27]. The Mars Van Krevelen mechanism is commonly accepted in oxidation processes on metallic oxides. These catalysts contain a redox pair that favors electronic transference and oxygen mobility in order to assure the re-oxidation of the reduced catalyst. Manganese oxides are known for their capacity to form oxides in different states of oxidation and participate as an oxidizing agent (Mn4+ +e− →Mn3+ +e− →Mn2+) or as a reducing agent (Mn2+ −e− →Mn3+ −e− →Mn4+) Mn, in both cases, acts as an active component of a redox system [12]. The results by H2-TPR reveal that ACMn1.0 shows the best redox behavior under reaction conditions (<500°C), which favors electronic and oxygen mobility thereby promoting the higher activity of ACMn1.0. 3.2 Cobalt oxides In Fig. 9 , the XRD patterns of the cobalt oxides prepared by auto-combustion and co-precipitation methods employing the ratio Co/Mg=1 are displayed. The oxides ACCo1.0 and CPCo1.0 present the same oxide phases; this result is evidence that the preparation method does not have a great influence on the cobalt-species formed or is not appreciable by XRD. The formation of CoO or Co2O3 oxides are not identified by XRD in any catalyst; therefore, we concluded that the Co3+/2+ ions are located in spinel-like structures, possibly such as CoAl2O4, Co2AlO4 and Co3O4 (JCPDS N° 44-0160; JCPDS N° 30-0814; JCPDS N° 42-1467) whose maxima are difficult to differentiate. The peak at 19° 2θ can be an indication of the presence of Co3+/2+ and/or Co3O4, which is incorporated into the Mg–Al spinel phase [44]. The XRF analysis of the cobalt oxides ACCo1.0 and CPCo1.0 (Table 1) exhibit M2+/M3+ ratios close to 3, although this ratio is slightly greater in the case of auto-combustion. Likewise, the Co2+/Mg2+ ratio is larger in this solid and indicates an effective incorporation of cobalt by means of this methodology. The H2-TPR profiles for cobalt oxides appear in Fig. 10 , where two zones are revealed. The first zone between 100 and 500°C is attributed to the oxide-reduction process of cobalt to metallic cobalt: Co3O4 +H2 →3CoO+H2O 3CoO+3H2 →3Co+3H2O The second zone of high temperatures (>500°C) is associated to the presence of Co–Al type species that have a strong interaction in the solid solution [45,46]. ACCo1.0 presents four reduction peaks in the low temperature zone with maxima at 210, 355, 405 and 430°C. These signals are attributed to the gradual reduction of Co3O4 with different particle sizes to CoO and metallic Co. The first two peaks are assigned to Co3O4 and its reduction to CoO and the third and fourth, to the reduction of CoO to Co [2,47] According to Potoczna-Petru and Kępiński [48] in an investigation regarding Co3O4 reduction followed by electronic microscopy, the reduction temperature is greatly influenced by particle size. Particles with sizes less than 53Å are totally reduced to metallic cobalt at temperatures lower than 300°C. If the particle size is greater than 121Å, the reduction peak shifts, and a peak at 420°C is assigned to the reduction of CoO to metallic cobalt [49]. The H2-TPR of the catalyst prepared by AC suggests that it contains Co3O4 in a wide range of particle sizes and chemical environments that favor the reductive process. On the other hand, ACCo1.0 presents a shift toward lower temperatures for the signal of the second zone. This behavior can be associated with the presence of cobalt species having less interaction with the solid solution. These cobalt species are promoted by the short synthesis of the auto-combustion method, which prevents a complete miscibility of the material's components decreasing the reduction temperatures. Moreover, the narrow range of particle sizes and the formation of defects in the solid generated by this methodology facilitates the reduction of the species [24]. Even though important differences appear in the H2-TPR profiles of the oxides prepared by the two synthesis methods, hydrogen consumption was the same for both solids (Table 2). The specific areas (Table 1) of the cobalt oxides have lesser values than those obtained for the Mn oxides. The isotherms are of type IV and type II for ACCo1.0 and CPCo1.0, respectively, as in the case of the Mn oxides. In spite of the area of solid CPCo1.0 being slightly greater than ACCo1.0, this property is not a determining factor in the catalytic behavior, as is shown in Table 3. The catalytic performance is the same with both materials. These results correlate with the XRD and H2-TPR analyses, which reveal the same phases and similar hydrogen consumption for both catalysts. The results of the characterization and catalytic activity (Fig. 11 ) show that the redox properties and catalytic behavior of the manganese oxides are more important when the auto-combustion methodology is used. On the contrary, this method does not have much influence on the cobalt oxides that are equivalent to the oxides prepared by co-precipitation. This behavior can be explained by the effect of the glycine in the auto-combustion reaction because the glycine acts as a chelating and a combustible oxidant at the same time; thus, the stability of the glycine–manganese (log β =3.2) and the glycine–cobalt (log β =5.2) compounds influence the intensity in auto-combustion and, therefore, the properties of the materials obtained [50]. Manganese provides more intense combustion and quicker reactions due to its high capacity of electronic transference. The greater stability of the cobalt–glycine complex generates more involvement by the ligand electrons in the chelation with the metal and decreases the reducing power of the fuel. As a consequence, the auto-combustion reaction between the nitrate and the glycine will be less intense leading to prolonged reaction times and lesser creation of defects. Because the auto-combustion reaction is a redox process in which the metal is able to give electrons to the fuel, changing the oxidation state will lead to the metal that best promotes the combustion reaction and, therefore, materials with more interesting properties from the catalytic point of view [51]. On the other hand, manganese nitrate can have a higher activity than cobalt nitrate with respect to glycine efficiency in the combustion process. Ianoş et al. [52] found differences in the behavior of Mg(NO3)2 and Al(NO3)3 with respect to β-alanine. The experimental results showed that, while Al(NO3)3 reacts in a difficult way with β-alanine, in approximately 240s, the Mg(NO3)2 reacts extremely violently with β-alanine. In the same way, the manganese reacts faster than the cobalt with the glycine-producing oxides and with better properties in oxidation reactions. Additionally, the difference in the catalytic performance between ACMn1.0 and ACCo1.0 is attributed to the redox properties of the two catalysts. Table 2 shows the uptake of H2 at lower temperatures (<500°C) and their total consumption. This results evidence that around 84% of the Mn species is available to carry out the oxidation of the VOC under reaction conditions (<500°C) while 28% of the Co is reduced at these temperatures in the solid ACCo1.0. The low consumption of H2 in reaction conditions (<500°C) for the Co is attributed mainly to the facility of this metal to form solid solutions with the aluminum (Co–Al). Thus, the presence of Al avoids the reduction of cobalt ions at low temperatures as is shown by the H2-TPR for cobalt oxides (Fig. 10) [53]. Likewise, it is known that the reduction temperatures are related to oxygen mobility. High reduction temperatures decrease the oxygen mobility in the network of catalyst and reduce the catalytic behavior in the oxidation of toluene [10]. Therefore, ACMn1.0 has stronger redox properties than ACC01.0, indicating that the oxygen mobility is stronger in ACMn1.0. This factor primarily determines the higher activity of ACMn1.0 compared to ACCo1.0. Finally, the mixed oxides Mn–Mg–Al and Co–Mg–Al prepared by the auto-combustion method are shown to be effective in toluene conversion with similar results as coprecipitation oxides but can be obtained in very short times with good physicochemical and catalytic properties. 4 Conclusions Mn–Mg–Al and Co–Mg–Al catalysts were obtained by the auto-combustion and co-precipitation methods. An increase in the manganese load favors the formation of Mn3O4 species that are fundamental in oxidation reactions. ACMn1.0 shows the best catalytic behavior in toluene oxidation. This catalyst overcomes the catalytic activity of the solid with the same manganese load prepared by the co-precipitation method, CPMn1.0. The cobalt oxides prepared by the two synthesis routes present similar textural, structural, redox and catalytic properties. These results are evidence that the preparation methodology does not have the same effect in the cobalt solid as with the manganese oxide. The auto-combustion methodology reduces the time of synthesis and promotes the redox properties of the oxides. The manganese reacts faster than the cobalt with the glycine and produces oxides with better properties in oxidation reactions. This method obtains active and selective manganese catalysts in total toluene oxidation. coredata.dc:description: Manganese oxides were prepared by the auto-combustion method and while employing variable Mn/Mg ratios from 0.1 to 1.0 with glycine as a combustible and a glycine/nitrate=1 ratio. The Mn/Mg ratio that showed the best activity in the oxidation of toluene was maintained in order to synthesize the hydrotalcite structure by the co-precipitation method, which by calcination, allows the formation of a mixed oxide. Cobalt oxides were prepared by the two synthesis methods while maintaining the best metal charge (corresponding to the best catalytic behavior). The obtained solids were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray fluorescence (XRF), temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and surface area measurements, and the catalytic activity for the complete toluene oxidation was evaluated. The results revealed that the auto-combustion catalysts are obtained in very short times and that their physico-chemical and catalytic properties are the same or higher than those of the co-precipitation catalysts. The solid with the Mn/Mg=1 ratio is the most active and selective catalyst and shows more activity than the oxide obtained by the co-precipitation method. The redox behavior in the manganese catalysts depends on the preparation method, which, in the case of auto-combustion, avoids the segregation of phases. The manganese reacts faster than the cobalt with the glycine and produces oxides with better properties in oxidation reactions. On the contrary, the cobalt oxides prepared by the two synthesis methods with a Co/Mg=1 ratio presented similar results in toluene oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: Mn–Co–Al–Mg mixed oxides by auto-combustion method and their use as catalysts in the total oxidation of toluene
